moves.1. f4: Not an uncommon opening. The idea is to get the KBP forward before planting the KN on the natural square, enabling this P to participate in a K-side thrust. And of course to veer down less explored paths than, say, the Queen's Gambit or the Ruy Lopez.
moves.2... Nf6 3. e3: This opening is almost a mirror reflection of the English Opening. In that one, White plays P-QB4 and N-QB3, focusing on the light squares in the center. Here, White's focus is on the dark central squares.
moves.3... Bg4 4. h3: Naturally I have no intention of letting Black maintain the pin on my Knight.
moves.4... Bxf3 5. Qxf3: I wasn't expecting Black to so willingly give up a minor exchange.
moves.6... e6 7. Bb2: ...and increase my hold on the central dark squares.
moves.7... Be7 8. Be2: Time to focus on completing my development.
moves.8... O-O 9. d3: To clear Q2 for the Knight and avoid obstructing the long diagonal.
moves.9... c5 10. c4: Turning up the heat on Black's central pawns.
moves.10... Ra7 11. Nd2: The back rank is clear now.
moves.15... Qd2 16. Bd3: Saving the B and threatening QxRP mate.
moves.16... g6 17. Rab1: The mate threat gave me time to guard the other B as well.
moves.17... Rd8 18. Rfd1: Naturally, I want to drive Black's Q from the heart of my position. I was expecting 18... Q-N5.
moves.18... f5 19. Qe5: Black's Q is still en prise, but I now have an additional threat...
